releasenotes/notes/bug-1851545-781c35893.message: Per commit message, could we add an online migration to populate this? I guess we need some way to map the InstancePCIRequest object to the neutron port associated with it. This is easy for instances with a single SR-IOV port, which I suspect will be a lot of them. For instances with multiple SR-IOV ports, I think we could look at the PCI device information in the port binding, find the matching host 'PciDevice' object for the port binding, and then find the matching 'InstancePCIRequest' object based on the 'PciDevice.request_id' field. If we cache the port binding information from neutron anywhere, it might even be possible do this entirely offline?

So I've been thinking about this.

First, let's say right off the bat that an online data migration makes backporting this impossible.

Second, the data migration would have to find all ACTIVE instances with SRIOV ports, and update the InstancePCIRequest.requester_id to the port UUID. Even for instances with multiple ports, we can probably correlate by pci_slot or something, so that's doable. But there's an open question for instances that are not ACTIVE. For instance, SHELVED(_OFFLOADED) instances cannot be data-migrated in such a fashion. Or for instances in MIGRATING, we might run into race conditions depending on whether we run the migration before or after we've updated the port bindings.

So since there are open questions about the data migration, I'd like to propose that we keep this fix patch separate (and backportable!), and hash out the data migration in a separate patch on top.

This depends on how we do the online migration. We could do it by way of the "on load" pattern, like we do when populating the uuid field of PciDevice (via the '_from_db_object' classmethod).

Agree that we can do this afterwards. I would like to see a WIP patch sitting on top before we send this through and forget about it though. I'll see if I can draft something tomorrow, seeing as you're off this week.

tempest/api/image/v2/test_images.py.message:
This is doing a different thing than my original implementation. The tasks API will normally be disabled for regular users and thus this should fail with the primary credentials. We expose just the relevant tasks under image/$id/tasks so that regular users can see when a task for their image is done.

During the RBAC work this last cycle, we realized that the defaults-in-code, the sample file, and what devstack ends up with are all inconsistent and we have work planned for this cycle to refactor all of the policy layer to fix this.

So, I would expect that a real cloud would not be able to run this test anymore because the regular users can't see tasks via the /tasks/$task_id API, but this will also break when we fix the default policies.

Ideally, we'd just poll on show_image-tasks() from L108...

I see, if that is admin by default (in future, as currently it seems open for all[1]) then we can avoid using that API so that this test can be non-admin test.

But I get your point of validating the workflow in same way users are supposed to do. 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/policies/tasks.py#L42

Just to be clear: the thing this test is supposed to be validating is that we can see and follow the task status from the images/$id/tasks API as a regular user, as that's a new feature and is added so people can do an import and poll for completion. We're not checking it in this test just to make sure the tasks finishes, we're trying to actually validate that workflow of polling for task completion via images/$id/tasks, so changing this test in this way removes that validation.

TBH, I'm not sure why you're able to hit this with os_primary creds, as we have a master control on /tasks/* that requires admin for those...

There's no longer an 'else' case; is there anything to log/handle in such case where it no longer meets these conditions (though has mnfa_host_count which is also being decremented in this method) ?

The intent here is to prevent host recovery until heartbeat is recovered on ALL monitored interfaces. If we get a clear for one monitored network then without this change the node will be recovered. Note this in the commit message.

- Prevent successful Graceful Recovery until all heartbeat
   monitored networks recover.
   Reason: If heartbeat of one network, say cluster recovers but
           another (management) does not then its possible the
           max Graceful Recovery Retries could be reached quite
           quickly, while one network recovered but the other
           may not have, causing maintenance to fail the host and
           force a full enable with reboot.

What is here is intended and tested.

mtce/src/heartbeat/hbsAgent.cpp.message: no longer needed to send_clear in this case?

That's correct. This change maps directly to this commit message fix.

- Prevent the hbsAgent from sending heartbeat clear events
   to maintenance in response to a heartbeat stop command.
   Reason: Maintenance receiving these clear events while in
           Graceful Recovery causes it to pop out of graceful
           recovery only to re-enter as a retry and therefore
           needlessly consumes one (of a max of 5) retry count.

mtce/src/maintenance/mtcCtrlMsg.cpp.message: I suppose this will now apply to AIO Duplex, and not AIO Simplex, since excludes active host in order to get here.

This is handling of the hbsAgent 'ready event' indicating that the hbsAgent has 'restarted' and needs the inventory sent to it.

In this case we only want to send the 'start' heartbeat under the above conditions. The AIO is special in that we can't start heartbeat until/unless the subfunction is configured successfully and 'goenabled' tested ok.

This system type compare ensures that the subfunction aspect is only considered for AIO controllers. In an AIO plus system there are computes and we don't want the subfunction to be considered for those but (again) do for the AIO controllers.

I hope this makes the code change here clearer.

This was explicitly test in an AIO Plus system and was the test that was holding up the last -1 WF.

validations_libs/utils.py.message:
I think, this should not be done here in this function.
We already have a mechanism  in constants.py and btw the os.environ.get is wrong, since PWD is always set.

I'd rather avoid using PWD since it might change over time. Using it would therefore mean we end with logs everywhere on the system, which is.... meh.

It would probably make more sense using /tmp as a fallback - even if it's not a "permanent" location (gets emptied upon reboot, for instance), nor a secure one (anyone can access it)... But at least, we get a single location, usable by any user/process. WDYT?

The issue lies in the env/user/installation-procedure permutations. 
If we were certain that the user running the validation in particular env, will have access to, say /tmp, that would be great. But we don't have that assurance.

We can, and we should, centralize this mechanic as utility function. But it's going to be a bit more complex. I'm abandoning the patch and going back to the design. Thanks for the feedback.

The constants.py checks only for existence. Permissions are determined here.
So when the folder exists, but isn't accessible, this will simply fail, and print out a nice exception message. 

But it doesn't help the user beyond diagnostics. Now, instead of just saying what went wrong, it will try to put the logs in home folder, if the process owner has one, or in PWD, which is, as you noted, always set. 

And it will log an exception and warning, with both the original, and final path.

This way we will have logs dir under almost any circumstances and the customer will be notified of the issue. Not to mention the fact that it will simplify our diagnostics of future issues, as we will now know, where did the process attempt to make a logdir.

Oops, I forgot the negation while I was writing.
PWD is NOT always set, so it not should be as default.

For the rest, the function should raise an exception, but not fallback into a directory.
The fallback thing, should be done only in one place, otherwise, it's difficult to find what happen and where.
The constants.py can even check rights as in the callback validation_json.py.

In your proposal, the "run" part will right into $HOME if the log directory is not writable, but the constant will still look into the unwritable place for the rest of the code.

ironic/drivers/modules/ilo/boot.py.message: Configuration will not be read from the virtual media, so the token can't be pre-generated. So a choice exists. Master everything for specific nodes all the time, OR not.   if cleaving_context.cursor:

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/cert_mon/uti.message: I don't think this will be able to detect the case where the new admin endpoint cert is signed by old ICA cert all the time. If the old ICA is not expired, the test will pass as the old ICA cert is still signed by the DC root CA, the chain verification will succeed.

That is the bug we are trying to address. When everything works as intended, we will have the correct "old-old" or "new-new" combination of ICA-AdminEP certs. The bug is a condition that where we had a "old-new" ICA-AdminEP combo in 2% of the cases.

Here, we are trying to distinguish if the ICA signs the AdminEP cert is the one we get from the k8s secret rather than assuming that cert-manage has used the correct ICA.

Ok,if we want to capture all the rare cases, I think we could run the verification command a second time, and for the second run, retrieve the ICA cert from DC_ADMIN_ROOT_CA_SECRET_NAME (instead of SC_ADMIN_ENDPOINT_SECRET_NAME), and use it as the 'untrusted' cert in the verification command. The rare case could be a timing issue between endpoint cert is issued and the ICA cert is renewed.

I took another look at the Jira. It complains that the admin endpoint is signed by an old ICA cert. But in the reported case, even though the admin endpoint cert is signed by an old ICA cert, the cert chain seems still passed "openssl s_client" verificiation. (verify return:1). This error case would pass the above "verify_adminep_cert_chain()" as well.

Yes we cannot use the old ca.crt to verify the new tls.crt. But my concern is, you retrieve both the ca.crt and tls.crt from the same secret, where the tls.crt is always signed by the ca.crt, so they are always valid. In other words, the ca.crt and tls.crt could be either "old - old" or "new - new", both will pass the verification.

ICA renewal comes with private key update. So ICA can be detected whether it is part of the certificate chain to sign the endpoint certificate. The command is to verify that. Will be nice to have a quick test to verify the command.

Tested to confirm the behavior. If there is a mismatch of ca.crt and the tls.crt in the k8s secret data (i.e., an old ICA was used), the openssl command fails the check. Yes, combination of old ca.crt and old tls.crt will still return valid chain, but we cannot use the old ca.crt to verify the new tls.crt.

See output of test below.

controller-0:~/tmp$ openssl verify -CAfile /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors/dc-adminep-root-ca.crt -untrusted old/ca.crt old/tls.crt
old/tls.crt: OK
controller-0:~/tmp$ openssl verify -CAfile /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors/dc-adminep-root-ca.crt -untrusted new/ca.crt new/tls.crt
new/tls.crt: OK
controller-0:~/tmp$
controller-0:~/tmp$ openssl verify -CAfile /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors/dc-adminep-root-ca.crt -untrusted old/ca.crt new/tls.crt

That's what was expected. But in a case (this bug), the ICA being used to signed the ep certificate was the one before renewed. The check here is to detect this situation that cert-manager uses outgoing ICA to sign new ep certificate.

The issue here is that the ca_tmpfile.name is retrieved from k8s secret.data['ca.crt'], which will always be the signing ICA certificate of the admin ep certificate (retrieved from secret.data['tls.crt']. It can be the old ICA cert (that could be the case reported in the LP).  And in this case, as the old ICA cert is still valid, the verification command will still succeed.

Sorry, I mean "sc-adminep-ca-certificate" in subcloud sc-cert namespace.

controller-0:~$ kubectl get secret -n sc-cert
NAME                        TYPE                                  DATA   AGE
default-token-pqn7g         kubernetes.io/service-account-token   3      44h
sc-adminep-ca-certificate   kubernetes.io/tls                     2      44h
sc-adminep-certificate      kubernetes.io/tls                     3      44h

controller-0:~$ kubectl get secret sc-adminep-ca-certificate -n sc-cert
NAME                        TYPE                DATA   AGE
sc-adminep-ca-certificate   kubernetes.io/tls   2      44h

This is the ICA cert that signs the admin endpoint certificate. It should be the same as the ca.crt retrieved from "sc-adminep-certificate". But I suspect they are different in the rare error case (one maybe new and the other is old).

We are running this piece of verification code on the subcloud (also includes 3x retries as per the code change in this commit in watcher.py). The DC_AMDIN_ROOT_CA_SECRET_NAME is part of 'dc-cert' namespace, which is only available on the central syscontroller, not on subclouds. The syscontroller runs a periodic full audit already.

I think we should not catch and eat these 2 exceptions if somehow k8s secret data isn't accessible or intact. The 'uncaught exception' will be caught at watcher layer (watcher.py line 234) to reattempt the update event in error path.

It isn't only going to affect bullseye, that's just the first release it will affect. I'd like to suggest a different approach.  How about we do just return the raw data structure, and defer to the REST api docs (and improve them where needed)?

That way we aren't spending our time copying the docs from the rest api to here, and doing a bunch of boilerplate object initialization.  It makes maintaining the client much easier.

I just wrote a patch to nodepool that essentially dropped the azure sdk in favor of a much simpler system of just passing through rest api data.  That's partly because the microsoft sdk was inefficient in some operations, but also because it was slightly different than the rest api, but its documentation wasn't as good.  I've found it much easier to just use the rest api docs directly.  I think the same thing would benefit us in zuul too.
